newsitem.title: UK: Second "whip" named in alleged UK sleaze cover-up.
newsitem.headline: Second "whip" named in alleged UK sleaze cover-up.

text.p: The government's difficulties over allegations that it tried to stifle an investigation of sleaze claims involving a former minister deepened on Tuesday.

A member of parliament of the opposition Labour Party produced a letter that he said showed a deliberate attempt by the government in 1994 to influence the probe into allegations of influence-peddling against ex-trade minister Neil Hamilton.

The MP, Dale Campbell-Savours, distributed the letter during the second day of questioning by parliament's powerful Standards and Privileges Committee of junior minister David Willetts, a high-flyer who is a close adviser to Prime Minister John Major.

Stripped of the minutiae of parliament's murky working methods, the central question of whether there was a cover-up of sleaze claims has considerable potential to embarrass Major in the run-up to a general election he must call by next May.
The Privileges Committee is investigating whether Willetts, when he was a "whip" or government business manager, improperly tried to influence a panel of MPs probing Hamilton.
The former minister was alleged to have accepted cash and favours for asking parliamentary questions on behalf of Mohammed al Fayed, owner of London's up-market Harrods department store.
With no warning to fellow members of the committee, Campbell-Savours handed around a letter that he said was written by another former whip who is now a minister, Andrew Mitchell.
In the purported letter, Mitchell reported to the Chief Whip on a conversation he had about Hamilton with a senior parliamentary official.
"I put it to you that there was a deliberate, very effective effort made by the Whips' Office... to try to influence this inquiry," Campbell-Savours told Willetts.
Willetts refused to comment on the document and insisted he had not tried to influence the committee investigating Hamilton.
The hearings, which are being televised, made front-page news in Britain on Tuesday after Willetts was accused by fellow Conservative Quentin Davies of deceiving the committee.

Davies returned to the attack on Tuesday, suggesting to Willetts that he had changed his account of a meeting in 1994 with the chairman of the Hamilton committee to protect the latter from embarrassment.
Willetts, whose career could be ruined if he is judged to have deliberately misled MPs, replied firmly: "There is no truth in the suggestion that I lied to this committee."
